prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In this frequency setup, we mainly observe DNC, CS, and CH3OH lines. The velocity resolution should be better than 0.4 km s-1. We use 234.375 MHz bandwidth mode with averaging the 4 channels. We use Baseband-2 with the 937 MHz mode for the caliblation. In the observed bands, many hot core tracers (e.g. CH3CH2CN) can be observed.

We investigate the thermal Jeans fragmentation process in the clumps. For the purpose, we need 0.3" resolution, which corresponds to 1000 AU at the distance of 3.6 kpc. This is about 4 times smaller than the Jeans length at a temperature of 10 K and a density of 10^6 cm-3. Since we investigate the fragmentation in the dense regions of the clumps, the extended emission is not important. Without ACA, we can cover the structure with a size of 4", which is enough for covering a dense core.

The main target line of this science goal is DNC J=3-2. In our ALMA cycle 0 data toward the IRDC clump G34.43+00.24 MM3, the DNC emission is detected about 30 mJy/beam with a beam size of 0.8". The distance to G34.43+00.24 MM3 is derived to be ~1.5 kpc by the VLBI observations (Kurayama et al. 2011, PASJ, 63, 514). The physical scale of 0.8" at a distance of 1.5 kpc is comparable to that of ~0.3" at a distance of 3.6 kpc. Thus, we request a rms noise of 5 mJy/beam to detect the 25 mJy/beam emission with 5 sigma. Since the velocity width is about 2 km s-1, we adopt the velocity resolution of 0.4 km s-1. The mass of the core in G34.43+00.24 MM3 is <1 Msun (Sakai et al. 2013, ApJ, 775, L31), so that we can investigate the DNC/HNC ratio in small cores in the HMPO clumps. However, there is a possibility that the distance to G34.43+00.24 MM3 is 3.5 kpc (e.g. Sakai et al. 2006, ApJ, 678, 1049). Even if this is the case, we can investigate the DNC/HNC ratio in the cores with the mass of several Msun. The CS and CH3OH emission is expected to be stronger than the DNC emission.

In this frequency setup, we mainly observe HN13C, H13CO+, HN13C, and SiO lines. The velocity resolution should be better than 0.4 km s-1 for HN13C, H13CO+, and HN13C. For HN13C, H13CO+, and HN13C, we use 234.375 MHz bandwidth mode with averaging the 4 channels. Since the linewidth of SiO is thought to be larger than that of the other lines, we use the 937 MHz mode for the SiO observation, and use this baseband for the calibration. In the observed bands, many hot core tracers (e.g. HCOOCH3) can be observed.

We investigate the thermal Jeans fragmentation process in the clumps. For the purpose, we need 0.3" resolution, which corresponds to 1000 AU at the distance of 3.6 kpc. This is about 4 times smaller than the Jeans length at a temperature of 10 K and a density of 10^6 cm-3. Since we investigate the fragmentation in the dense regions of the clumps, the extended emission is not important. Without ACA, we can cover the structure with a size of 4", which is enough for covering a dense core.

The main target line of this science goal is HN13C J=3-2. In our ALMA cycle 0 data toward the IRDC clump G34.43+00.24 MM3, the HN13C emission is detected about 20 mJy/beam with a beam size of 0.8". We request a rms noise of 5 mJy/beam, which is the same as that of setup 1. We can detect the 20 mJy/beam emission with 4 sigma. Since the velocity width is about 2 km s-1, we adopt the velocity resolution of 0.4 km s-1. The H13CO+ and SiO emission is expected to be stronger than the HN13C emission.

In this frequency setup, we mainly observe N2H+, CH3OH maser, and DCN. The velocity resolution should be better than 0.4 km s-1 for N2H+, CH3OH maser, DCN. For N2H+, CH3OH maser, DCN, we use 234.375 MHz bandwidth mode with averaging the 4 channels. We use Baseband-3 with 937.5 MHz mode for the calibration. In the observed bands, many hot core tracers (e.g. CH3CH2CN) can be observed.

We investigate the thermal Jeans fragmentation process in the clumps. For the purpose, we need 0.3" resolution, which corresponds to 1000 AU at the distance of 3.6 kpc. This is about 4 times smaller than the Jeans length at a temperature of 10 K and a density of 10^6 cm-3. Since we investigate the fragmentation in the dense regions of the clumps, the extended emission is not important. Without ACA, we can cover the structure with a size of 4", which is enough for covering a dense core.

The main target line of this science goal is N2H+ J=3-2. In our ALMA cycle 0 data toward the IRDC clump G34.43+00.24 MM3, the N2H+ emission is detected about 200 mJy/beam with a beam size of 0.8". To detect the 50 mJy/beam emission above 5 sigma level, we request a rms noise level of 10 mJy/beam. Since the velocity width is about 2 km s-1, we adopt the velocity resolution of 0.4 km s-1. The CH3OH maser line is expected to be stronger than the N2H+ line.

We use Baseband-2 with the 937 MHz mode for the caliblation. In the observed bands, many hot core tracers (e.g. CH3CH2CN) can be observed.

For HN13C, H13CO+, and HN13C, we use 234.375 MHz bandwidth mode with averaging the 4 channels. Since the linewidth of SiO is thought to be larger than that of the other lines, we use the 937 MHz mode for the SiO observation, and use this baseband for the calibration. We request a rms noise of 5 mJy/beam, which is the same as that of setup 1. We can detect the 20 mJy/beam emission with 4 sigma. Since the velocity width is about 2 km s-1, we adopt the velocity resolution of 0.4 km s-1. The H13CO+ and SiO emission is expected to be stronger than the HN13C emission.

For N2H+, CH3OH maser, DCN, we use 234.375 MHz bandwidth mode with averaging the 4 channels. We use Baseband-3 with 937.5 MHz mode for the calibration. In the observed bands, many hot core tracers (e.g. CH3CH2CN) can be observed.

Without ACA, we can cover the structure with a size of 4", which is enough for covering a core.

To detect the 50 mJy/beam emission above 5 sigma level, we request a rms noise level of 10 mJy/beam. Since the velocity width is about 2 km s-1, we adopt the velocity resolution of 0.4 km s-1. The CH3OH maser line is expected to be stronger than the N2H+ line.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: For understanding the cluster formation mechanisms, it is very important to reveal how dense cores are formed in massive clumps, and how and when the mass of each cluster member is determined. To address these questions, we would like to observe on-going cluster-forming clumps in DNC and HN13C J=3-2 at a high angular resolution (0.3"), and to determine DNC/HNC ratio of the dense cores embedded in the clumps. The DNC/HNC ratio in star forming regions can reflect the timescale of their cold starless phase. Thus, we investigate from the DNC/HNC ratio of each resolved core whether the core was formed in an earlier stages or a later stages of cluster formation, and understand the core formation history in the clumps. For the purpose, we observe 2 high-mass protostellar objects, I18089-1732 MM1 and I18264-1152 MM1, which have the lowest and highest DNC/HNC ratio in the previous single-dish observations (Sakai et al. 2012), respectively. By comparing the results these two sources, we would also like to assess the diversity of cluster formation mechanism (i.e. fragmentation). The present observations propose for ALMA Cycle 3 are the first important step for future statistical studies.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Science, The University of Tokyo
